context: Published evidence of Birmingham aquifer contamination has been obtained from licensed abstraction wells that yield an integrated quality measurement (wells typically screen ∼100 m of sandstone). Groundwater inorganic quality data (Ford and Tellam, 1994) show increasing acidity with time, generally high nitrate and barium and localised high metals and ammonia. In terms of VOC groundwater quality, Rivett et al. (1990) identified chlorinated solvents, in particular TCE, to be the main VOCs of concern. Industrial sources of TCE and to a lesser extent 1,1,1-TCA have abounded in Birmingham within metal-cleaning applications with more limited use of PCE in textile dry-cleaning. Recent aquifer-survey data (Rivett et al., 2005; Shepherd et al., 2006) confirm a continued dominance of TCE and other chlorinated VOCs with only limited occurrence of aromatic hydrocarbon VOCs and fuel oxygenates. Our informal contact with environmental consultants operating across Birmingham suggests that many industrial sites contain locally high concentrations of VOCs in on-site soils and groundwaters; such data are unpublished. Riverbed piezometer monitoring network Field data were primarily obtained from a network of drivepoint riverbed piezometers.
